t: Job 24
Job Complains of Violence on the Earth
“Since*ipn times are not hidden from the Almighty, Why*ld do those who know Him see not His days?
“Some*iln remove landmarks; They*ld seize flocks violently and feed on*i them;*i
They*ld drive away the donkey of the fatherless; They*ld take the widow’s ox as a pledge.
They*ld push the needy off the road; All*ld the poor of the land are forced to hide.
Indeed,*ld like*i wild donkeys in the desert, They*ld go out to their work, searching for food. The*ld wilderness yields*i food for them and*i for their*i children.
They*ld gather their fodder in the field And*ld glean in the vineyard of the wicked.
They*ld spend the night naked, without clothing, And*ld have no covering in the cold.
They*ld are wet with the showers of the mountains, And*ld huddle around the rock for want of shelter.
“Some*iln snatch the fatherless from the breast, And*ld take a pledge from the poor.
They*ld cause the*i poor*i to go naked, without clothing; And*ld they take away the sheaves from the hungry.
They*ld press out oil within their walls, And*ld tread winepresses, yet suffer thirst.
The*ld dying groan in the city, And*ld the souls of the wounded cry out; Yet*ld God does not charge them*i with wrong.
“There*ln are those who rebel against the light; They*ld do not know its ways Nor*ld abide in its paths.
The*ld murderer rises with the light; He*ld kills the poor and needy; And*ld in the night he is like a thief.
The*ld eye of the adulterer waits for the twilight, Saying,*ld ‘No eye will see me’; And*ld he disguises his*i face.
In*ld the dark they break into houses Which*ld they marked for themselves in the daytime; They*ld do not know the light.
For*ld the morning is the same to them as the shadow of death; If*ld someone*i recognizes them,*i They*ild are*i in*i the terrors of the shadow of death.
“They*ln should*i be*i swift on the face of the waters, Their*ld portion should*i be*i cursed in the earth, So*ild that*i no one*i would*i turn into the way of their vineyards.
As*ld drought and heat consume the snow waters, So*ild the grave consumes*i those*i who*i have sinned.
The*ld womb should*i forget him, The*ld worm should*i feed sweetly on him; He*ld should*i be remembered no more, And*ld wickedness should*i be broken like a tree.
For*ld he preys on the barren who*i do not bear, And*ld does no good for the widow.
“But*ln God*i draws the mighty away with His power; He*ld rises up, but no man*i is sure of life.
He*ld gives them security, and they rely on*i it;*i Yet*ld His eyes are*i on their ways.
They*ld are exalted for a little while, Then*ld they are gone. They*ld are brought low; They*ld are taken out of the way like all others;*i They*ld dry out like the heads of grain.
“Now*ln if it*i is*i not so,*i who will prove me a liar, And*ld make my speech worth nothing?”
